name: PRIMED PGS Data Model
description: Data model for Genomic Summary Results in the PRIMED consortium

columns.description: unique identifier for an analysis in primed
Information about source of PGS data. Include additional details in README
URL of source (if applicable)
identifier in the PGS catalog
PubMed Identification number
The doi of each publication is curated in addition to the PMID to allow unpublished work (e.g. pre-prints) to be added to the catalog
Title of the publication
columns.examples: Prediction of Breast Cancer Risk Based on Profiling With Common Genetic Variants

columns.description: Last name and initials of the first author
The name of the publication source
columns.examples: Journal of the National Cancer Institute

columns.description: Date of publication (with respect to the PMID or doi upon upload to the Catalog)
External link to the publication
Publication ID from PGS catalog
This may be the name that the authors use to refer to the PGS, or a name that a curator has assigned to identify the score during the curation process (before a PGS ID has been given)
Reference genome assembly that the submitted data is mapped to
dbSNP build for the rsIDs included in PGS files
Total number of variants used to calculate the PGS
Number of higher-order variant interactions included in the PGS
The author-reported trait (e.g. body mass index [BMI], or coronary artery disease) that the PGS has been developed to predict
The Reported Trait is mapped to Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) terms and their respective identifiers by PGS Catalog curators
The Experimental Factor Ontology ID (EFO_ID) identifier to consistently refer to traits using the EFO, and to other resources like the NHGRI-EBI GWAS Catalog
Detailed description of the trait from EFO
columns.examples: A carcinoma that arises from epithelial cells of the breast

columns.description: Other names for the trait
Includes references to terms in other databases and ontologies (e.g. ICD9/ICD10, MONDO, SNOMEDCT, etc.)
type of trait
columns.notes: determines which columns we need to check for in the data file

columns.description: unit of measurement for the reported trait (before transformation)
columns.notes: Report unit as something like 'binary',  'indicator', or 'categorical'  for non-quantitative traits

columns.description: transformation applied to the reported trait
a brief description of how the trait was measured or defined; additional details can be provided in the README
columns.notes: e.g. ICD codes used to identify cases/phenotypes in EHR data

columns.description: The name or description of the method or computational algorithm used for developing the score.
Describe key parameters used in the score. e.g. LD/SNP r2 threshold, significance/p-value threshold, fraction of causal variants (ρ)
workspace identifier for the analysis that was generated in PRIMED
name describing the sample set
columns.notes: Must be unique for a given pgs_analysis_id and stage

columns.description: Study Stage (Variant associations / Score development)
Total sample size in the analysis
columns.notes: When different markers have different sample sizes, e.g, due to missing genotypes, use max sample size across markers

columns.description: Number of cases
columns.notes: When different markers have different sample sizes, e.g, due to missing genotypes, use max number of cases across markers

columns.description: Number of controls
columns.notes: When different markers have different sample sizes, e.g, due to missing genotypes, use max number of controls across markers

columns.description: effective sample size = n_samp for quantitative traits  = 4/(1/n_case + 1/n_ctrl) for binary traits
columns.notes: When different markers have different sample sizes, e.g, due to missing genotypes, use max sample size across markers

columns.description: proportion of male participants
mean age of study participants
median age of study participants
minimum age of study participants
maximum age of study participants
mean age of study cases
median age of study cases
minimum age of study cases
maximum age of study cases
mean age of study controls
median age of study controls
minimum age of study controls
maximum age of study controls
A list of cohorts that collected the samples.
the concept or classification scheme used to categorize people into populations for this analysis
name given to a population that describes or classifies it according to the dimension along which it was identified
columns.examples: Chinese Americans | European Americans | African Americans

columns.description: proportion of participants from each population in the same order mapping to the values in the population_labels variable
Reported countries of recruitment
Reported countries of birth
For analysis that used a dataset in primed individual data model indicate its dataset_id

columns.notes: AnVIL requires entity id with naming convention <table_name>_id

columns.description: A valid md5 checksum
unique identifier for a pgs in primed
columns.notes: AnVIL upload workflow would generate this

columns.description: File path in cloud storage
Type of the file
chromosome included in the GSR data file
columns.notes: 'None' for data dictionary or README files

columns.description: Count of variants in the GSR data file
columns.notes: Leave blank for data dictionary or README files

columns.description: The SNP’s rs ID. This column also contains HLA alleles in the standard notation (e.g. HLA-DQA1*0102) that aren’t always provided with chromosomal positions.
Chromosome name/number associated with the variant.
Chromosomal position associated with the variant.

The allele that's dosage is counted (e.g. {0, 1, 2}) and multiplied by the variant's weight (effect_weight) when calculating score. The effect allele is also known as the 'risk allele'. Note: this does not necessarily need to correspond to the minor allele/alternative allele.
The other allele(s) at the loci. Note: this does not necessarily need to correspond to the reference allele.
columns.notes: Recommended by PGSC but not required.

columns.description: This is kept in for loci where the variant may be referenced by the gene (APOE e4). It is also common (usually in smaller PGS) to see the variants named according to the genes they impact.
This is a TRUE/FALSE variable that flags whether the effect allele is a haplotype rather than a single SNP. Constituent SNPs in the haplotype are semi-colon separated.
This is a TRUE/FALSE variable that flags whether the effect allele is a diplotype rather than a single SNP. Constituent SNPs in the haplotype are semi-colon separated.

This described whether the variant was specifically called with a specific imputation or variant calling method. This is mostly kept to describe HLA-genotyping methods (e.g. flag SNP2HLA, HLA*IMP) that gives alleles that are not referenced by genomic position.
This field describes any extra information about the variant (e.g. how it is genotyped or scored) that cannot be captured by the other fields.
Explanation of when this variant gets included into the PGS (e.g. if it depends on the results from other variants).

Value of the effect that is multiplied by the dosage of the effect allele (effect_allele) when calculating the score. Additional information on how the effect_weight was derived is in the weight_type field of the header, and score development method in the metadata downloads.

This is a TRUE/FALSE variable that flags whether the weight should be multiplied with the dosage of more than one variant. Interactions are demarcated with a _x_ between entries for each of the variants present in the interaction.
This is a TRUE/FALSE variable that flags whether the weight should be added to the PGS sum if there is at least 1 copy of the effect allele (e.g. it is a dominant allele).
This is a TRUE/FALSE variable that flags whether the weight should be added to the PGS sum only if there are 2 copies of the effect allele (e.g. it is a recessive allele).

Weights that are specific to different dosages of the effect_allele (e.g. {0, 1, 2} copies) can also be reported when the the contribution of the variants to the score is not encoded as additive, dominant, or recessive. In this case three columns are added corresponding to which variant weight should be applied for each dosage, where the column name is formated as dosage_#_weight where the # sign indicates the number of effect_allele copies.
Author-reported effect sizes can be supplied to the Catalog. If no other effect_weight is given the weight is calculated using the log(OR).
Author-reported effect sizes can be supplied to the Catalog. If no other effect_weight is given the weight is calculated using the log(HR).
Reported effect allele frequency, if the associated locus is a haplotype then haplotype frequency will be extracted.
columns.notes: Additional columns may be supplied as allelefrequency_effect_Ancestry: Reported effect allele frequency in a specific population.
AnVIL requires entity id with naming convention <table_name>_id

columns.description: md5 checksum for the file
absolute file path in cloud storage
path to the README
Number of unique subjects in file
